STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
December 21, 2021
Darnell Britt
Community Care Organization
18688 Joann
Detroit, MI 48205
RE: License #: CB820315857
Investigation #: 2022C0420004
Community Care Organization
Dear Mr. Britt:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat non-
compliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA and your
contract.
P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  517-335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 860-0787.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  517-335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820315857
Investigation #: 2022C0420004
Complaint Receipt Date: 10/06/2021
Investigation Initiation Date: 10/06/2021
Report Due Date: 12/05/2021
Licensee Name: Community Care Organization
Licensee Address: 18688 Joann
Detroit, MI 48205
Licensee Telephone #: Unknown
Administrator: Kendra Washington, Designee
Licensee Designee: Kendra Washington, Designee
Name of Facility: Community Care Organization
Facility Address: 18688 Joann
Detroit, MI 48205
Facility Telephone #: (313) 920-4268
Original Issuance Date: 07/30/2013
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 01/30/2020
Expiration Date: 01/29/2022
Capacity: Unknown
Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Staff members have left youths alone without food for two weeks. No
Staff refuse to purchase food, clothing, and toiletry items for the
youths.
Staff members have withheld the youths’ checks. No
On an unknown date, several staff members yelled, cursed, and No
threatened to throw a youth around and treat them like a girl.
Additional Findings Yes
III. METHODOLOGY
10/06/2021 Special Investigation Intake
2022C0420004
10/06/2021 Special Investigation Initiated – Telephone call
To the named complainant. Person answering denied making
complaint and hung up
10/06/2021 Contact-Telephone call received
Spoke with DHHS Worker X- this complaint not accepted
10/08/2021 Contact- Document Received
Email DHHS Permanency Collaboration Unit (PCU) Worker XX
10/12/2021 Contact- Document Received
Email DHHS PCU Worker XX
10/12/2021 Contact-Telephone call made
Spoke with Chief Administrator A related to the complaint and
need to investigate
10/12/2021 Contact- Telephone call made
Spoke with DHHS PCU Worker XX
10/15/2021 Contact- Telephone call made
Spoke with Program Manager B
10/15/2021 Contact- Document Sent
And Received- Text message to and from Program Manager B Re
needed contacts
10/15/2021 Contact- Telephone made
Interviewed Youth 1
10/15/2021 Contact- Telephone made
Interviewed Case Manager C
10/15/2021 Contact- Face to Face
IL House- Interviewed Youth 2, Staff D, and toured the
independent living home
2

10/15/2021 Contact-Face to Face
Balfour House- Interviewed Youth 3, Youth 4, Youth 5, Staff E and
toured the independent living home
10/18/2021 Contact- Telephone call received
Spoke with Program Manager B
10/18/2021 Contact- Telephone call made
Interviewed Youth 6
10/18/2021 Contact- Document Sent
Text to Program Manager B requesting a youth’s contact
information and asking about house hole damages and issues with
the basement. Text received back
10/19/2021 Contact- Telephone made
And received- Spoke with Youth 3
10/19/2021 Contact- Document Received
video
10/20/2021 Contact- Telephone call made
Spoke with Case Manager C
10/22/2021 Contact- Document Received
Text of photo from Program Manager B
10/26/2021 Contact-Face to Face
Met Case Manager C at Joanne IL home- obtained sign-off sheets
RE: Youth Stipends
10/27/2021 Contact- Telephone call made
Interviewed Case Manager F
10/27/2021 Contact- Telephone call made
Interviewed with Youth Advocate Supervisor Assistant G
11/22/2021 Inspection Complete- Sub Compliance
12/05/2021 Contact- Face to Face
Team conference- Exit
ALLEGATION:
 Staff members have left youths alone without food for two weeks.
 Staff refuse to purchase food, clothing, and toiletry items for the youths.
 Staff members have withheld the youths’ checks
INVESTIGATION:
On 10/6/2021 I reviewed the complainant document. It was not clear from the
complaint which one of the agency’s Independent Living (IL) homes this complaint
referred to. Additionally, Department of Health and Human Service (DHHS) Worker
X and I were investigating the Lakewood IL home and staff were available for the
shift, food was in the home.
On 10/6/2021 I attempted to speak with the Complainant. A male person answered
my call. He reported he was not the Complainant; he did not make a complaint and
hung up on me.
3

On 10/12/2021 I spoke with DHHS Permanency Collaboration Unit (PCU) Worker
XX. He advised the agency has at least 20 youths in IL placement. Not all of these
are in staffed homes. He indicated contact with a number of the youth POS
(Purchase of Service) DHHS Monitors. A couple of them reported the youth reported
some staff have withheld checks for youths not doing chores or attending life skill
classes.
On 10/12/2021 I spoke with Chief Administrator A by telephone about the complaint.
He expressed concern that an investigation for this complaint was being investigated
since the complaint does not name a staff or specific IL home. He reported, they
have four (one of which only has one youth due to COVID) staffed IL homes, all on
the eastside of Detroit. Chief Administrator A denied the allegations. He reported
the following:
 There have not been a time staff have left the youths in an IL home
unsupervised for 24-hours. Nor longer. The agency staffs the IL homes from
3:30pm until 7:00am. There is an afternoon shift (3:30pm-11:00pm) and
midnight shift (11:00pm-7:00am).
 They purchase food on occasion, especially when a youth first enters the
program; but youths are responsible for purchasing their own food.
 Clothing for a youth is not purchased, it’s not the agency’s responsibility. This
is an IL program, it’s the youths’ responsibility to purchase clothing.
 Bed sheets, and toiletries are provided when a youth is first placed. Chief
Administrator A reported it’s not his assertion that they must provide bedding
supplies for the youth, but they do so initially. Thereafter the youth is
responsible for the washing an upkeep of the bedding and towels. If the
youth needs these items and can’t get them, it’s the youth’s responsibility to
bring this to the agency’s attention, by addressing it with staff and the case
manager. Administrator A said they are constantly buying these items
because the youths mess up the items or use them to sleep on the floor. The
latter done at the youths’ own choosing.
 He affirmed his prior reporting that a youth’s check can be temporarily held for
not attending life skill courses, but staff do not do that.
On 10/15/2021 I spoke with Program Manager B by telephone about this complaint.
She affirmed Chief Administrator A’s reporting and added the following:
 They don’t provide the youth food, but if the youth reports not having food, they
will provide food. They have a pantry at one of the IL houses and will bring food
from that location to where the youth is located.
 They supply each youth sheets, towels, a comforter, and cleaning supplies when
the youth is first placed. The youth receive a “care package”. The agency also
keeps a linen closet of these items, so that if the youths needs these items, they
can assist the youth. The youths have been throwing these items away.
4

For this investigation I interviewed six youths: Youth 1 was interviewed by me by
telephone on 10/15/2021. Youth 2 was interviewed by me at one IL home; and Youth 3,
Youth 4, and Youth 5 were interviewed by me onsite at another IL home. I interviewed
Youth 6 who resides at yet a different IL home, by telephone on 10/18/2021.
All residents were asked the same general questions about the complaint issues.
 Youth 1 reported being at her current location by herself due to COVID.
Staff check on her a couple of times a day. When she was in the IL mom
and child home, it was staffed daily. There was never a time staff did not
work at the facility. She has a bridge card, but the agency bought her
grocery when she first arrived and didn’t ask for her bridge card. She
reported before she got sick and came to this current home on 10/5/2021
she knew she was to buy her own food, clothing, and toiletries. She had
sheets when she arrived in the IL program. She was provided a comforter,
towels, and soap. Program Manager B and Youth Advocate Supervisor
Assistant(YASA) G provided her with the former items, clothing detergent
and everything she needed. Youth 1 reported receiving a stipend check
every two weeks. She uses it to pay her rent. It is never withheld.
 Youth 2, Youth 3, Youth 4, Youth 5, and Youth 6 reported being in the
program for a year, four months, two months, four months, and seven
months respectively. Youth 3 and Youth 5 have resided at other IL homes
of this agency’s and relocated due to reason they reported not being clear
about. Youth 3 reported this being his second stay at this IL home. All of
these youths denied there being a time that staff left them unsupervised
for days or weeks without food. A couple of these youths varied with
respects to when staff arrive (3:30pm or 5:30pm) for their shifts, but all
admitted staff are normally onsite from the afternoon until 7:00am. Youth
2 reported Program Manager B also checks on them regularly.
Each of these youths affirmed Youth 1 and other staff reporting that they
are responsible for their own food, clothing, and personal items. Aside
from one of these youth complaining of the type of emergency food
provided, all admitted such assistance exits. In terms of stipend checks
they also affirmed receiving the funds every two weeks. Aside from a
couple of them reporting $147 is not enough, they reported the checks
being timely. All reported a check can be held one-two days for not doing
chores, curfew violations or not participating in life skills, but either
reported their checks being withheld. Youth 2 reported he follows the
rules. The other youths reported the IL contract rules were explained to
them.
Each of these five youths were aware that the agency provides bedding
items to residents. Youth 3 and Youth 6 said they came with their own
5

sheets. Youth 6 also reported fresh sheets are provided at first
placement. Youth 5 said there were sheets on his bed, but they were not
clean. Youth 5 reported the staff told him they would wash them, but he
ended up washing them himself.
Five staff were interviewed. They reported similarly information as Chief Administrator
A and Program Manager B related to the complaint issues:
 Case Manager C was interviewed by me via telephone on 10/15/2021 and
10/20/2021. She reported all the youths have bridge cards, but if a youth reports
they have run out of food the agency will assist the youth with food. She also
reported the agency has an emergency pantry and freeze with food located at
their Joanne IL home. A staff will obtain food from there and take to the resident,
if informed by the youth that the youth needs food. Case Manager C reported
both Youth 2 and Youth 4 have advised staff of such in the past, and the agency
provided them food. With respect to household items, like sheets, towels or
comforters, the exact item they provide depends on what the youth has at
placement. After that the youth is on his or her own to purchase more of those
items.
Case Manager C reported no awareness of a time that staff have not reported for
a shift and the youths were along when an afternoon and midnight shift was to be
covered, which is always. Case Manager C denied youth checks being withheld.
She said that is a constant complaint by the youths, but it’s not true. She
confirmed that the youths’ stipend checks arrive every two weeks. She said, they
now have the youths to sign a document showing the youth received their check.
She provided me some of such related to youths on her caseload.
 Staff D was interviewed onsite by me on 10/15/2021 at the Lakewood IL House.
He reported, the same related to food, bedding hygiene items being provided
initially, and after the youth being on their own. He reported his shift started at
3:00pm. Another staff will relieve him at 11:00pm and work until 7:00am. These
are the shifts where the youths are supervised. After 7:00pm the youths are on
their own and should be in school.
During my onsite visit at the Lakewood IL address, the staff gave me a tour. I
viewed and I checked the kitchen for both the upstairs and downstairs. Food
consisting of eggs, meat, cold cuts, milk, cereal, fruits, noodles, Rice Roni, and
some can goods, were observed appropriately in the refrigerator and or cabinets.
Staff D reported the youths purchased the food out of the youths’ stipends.
Youth 2 showed me his bedroom and linen was observed on his bed and he had
clothing and other items scattered about in the room.
6

 Staff E was interviewed onsite by me on 10/15/2021 at the Balfour IL House. She
said staff are to be onsite 15 minutes before their shift is to start. She said,
Program Manager B is good at making sure a staff is at the IL home. Staff E
reported the same general information as her coworkers related to issues of the
allegations.
During my onsite visit at the Balfour IL address, the staff gave me a tour of the
youth’s bedroom, the kitchen, refrigerator, cabinets, and the basement. Bedding
was seen on the beds. Foods, such as meats (hamburger, chicken, hot dogs),
fruit, milk, waffles, pop, chips, spaghetti, Rice-Roni, Chef-Boy-R-D, can string
beans and corn, cake mix, flour and condiments were observed in the home.
 Case Manager F was interviewed by me by telephone on 10/27/2021. She
reported when a youth first arrived at the program the staff will take the youth to
buy food until the youth’s bridge card case is opened. She reported that process
can takes 45-days and so the agency continues to buy food until the youth gets
their bridge card. She confirmed Case Manager C’s and the two administrators’
reporting on the other items. She added that youths do have chores and life
skills courses they are required to complete to be compliant in the program. A
youth’s check can be set aside for a day or two for the youth to complete those
items; and that’s in the youth’s contract. However, they understand the youth
needs their funds to buy things, so checks are not withheld.
 Youth Advocate Supervisor Assistant (YASA) G confirms basically all aspects as
reported by others. She reported the only window of time the youths are not
supervised is when they are in school from 8:00am- 3:00 pm. She reported a
staff person will report for the first supervisory shift at 3:00pm. She advised it’s
true that some staff may work from 3:00pm- 11:00pm; and others 5:30pm to
11:00pm. There is never a time a staff is not onsite at 3:00pm, unless that staff is
late or not able to come. If that’s the case, the staff person contacts the
supervisor or administrator. YASA G or someone else will fill in until the next
scheduled staff person arrives onsite.
YASA G reported similar information as Case Manager F with respect to youth
checks. She added, the case managers, not she, are responsible for handling
these stipend issues.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(1) An agency shall provide supervision for a youth in
independent living consistent with the youth's need for
supervision, as required by R 400.12504(2)(e).
7

ANALYSIS: The evidence does not support the allegations. The youths are
receiving regular supervision.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
ANALYSIS: The evidence does not support the allegations. The agency
assists the youths with needed items.
The youths receive initial groceries, bedding, and hygiene items
upon first placement into the program and food until their bridge
card and stipend account is opened. If the youth runs out of
food, emergency food is available and provided.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
On an unknown date, several staff members yelled, cursed, and threatened to throw
youth around and treat them like a girl.
INVESTIGATION:
On 10/12/2021 I spoke with Chief Administrator A by telephone about the complaint.
I spoke with Program Manager B about the complaint by telephone on 10/15/2021.
Both the Chief Administrator A and Program Manager B reported no awareness of
any youth being cursed, threatened, or called out of their name. No youth or staff
has reported such to them. Program Manager B reported when a youth enters their
programs, they advise the youth they are to be treated with dignity and respect; and
for them to report concerns related to staff misconduct.
Six youths were interviewed by me related to this complaint: Youth 1 was
interviewed by me by telephone on 10/15/2021. Youth 2 was interviewed by me
onsite at one IL home; and Youth 3, Youth 4, and Youth 5 were interviewed by me
onsite at a different IL home. I interviewed Youth 6 who resides at yet another IL
home by telephone on 10/18/2021.
 Youth 1 reported staff treats her with dignity and respect. She said, she was
not in any of the staff’s faces. She has a good relationship with her case
8

manager and Program Manager B. In the short time she has been in the
program, she has not observed or heard of any resident being cursed or
threatened. She admitted she has not been around other IL residents much
due to getting sick and needing to transfer to her current setting.
 Youth 2, Youth 4, and Youth 6 also reported feeling safe and treated with
respect. They denied any staff cursing or threatening them. Nor were they
aware of any other residents experiencing such.
 Youth 5 reported arguing with a staff and the staff yelling and threatening
him, but no other youth witnessed it. He and that staff are good now. Youth
5 also reported there was a time Staff H did not let him in the house, because
he was sitting on the porch after curfew. Youth 3 and YASA G were reported
to have information related to this.
 Youth 3 reported this was Youth 5’s fault and Youth 5 was let inside
the home after YASA G arrived.
 YASA G confirmed Youth 3’s reporting. She said Staff H contacted her
related to Youth 5 going on the porch then leaving after curfew; and
Staff H locked the door after Youth 5 left. YASA G reported it is
agency policy that if a youth arrived back at the facility after curfew,
the youth needs a police escort or pass to be allowed back. However,
in this incident Youth 5 didn’t actual leave the facility. Youth 5 reported
he went for a smoke. The matter was worked out quickly and Youth 5
was allowed back into the home.
 Youth 3 reported, he has anger issues, but keeps it under control and
professional, but staff yell and curse at them. He reported Case Manager C
did such to him in July 2021. Case Manager C threatened to throw him like a
girl, due to him being transgender. Youth 3 reported he was listening to
music and Case Manager C told him to clean his room. Case Manager C
entered his room and began throwing his clothing. He began videotaping her
because the administrator told them if staff do inappropriate things show
them with proof. He and Case Manager C were talking back, and forth and
Case Manager C told him to shut up and put her finger in his face. He told
Case Manager C to shut up and Case Manager C said she was an adult and
did not have too, and that she was not worried about him.
Five staff members were interviewed by me related to this complaint issue. Case
Manager C was interviewed by telephone on 10/15/2021, and 10/20/2021 Staff D,
and Staff E were interviewed onsite at different IL homes on 10/15/2021. Case
Manager E and YASA G were interviewed, separately by telephone on 10/27/2021.
 All the staff interviewed denied that any youth has complained or reported
to them that they were cursed, threatened by a staff member, or told a
staff would throw them around like a girl.
9

 Staff D, Staff E, Case Manager F, as well as Case Manager C all denied
doing such to any youth.
 Case Manager F acknowledged residents were advised to video tape
concerns of maltreatment. However, she denied awareness of any video
showing staff misconduct. Case Manager F reported no resident has
reported maltreatment by staff. She said if the resident don’t report such
to her, she can’t do anything about it.
 YASA G denied aware of a video or staff misconduct related to Youth 5.
Her reporting on the issue with Youth 3 is as previously indicated.
Reviewed:
A very brief video footage of an interaction between Case Manager C and Youth 3
which showed:
 Case Manager C and Youth 3 both talking loudly and telling the other they do
not have to shut up.
 Case Manager C on the footage, while Youth 3’s voice is heard. An
unidentified female youth (Reportedly no longer in the program) was heard
saying something which was not clear about Youth 3 and Case Manager 3
interaction; and later that it was embarrassing.
 Case Manager C was heard saying she is an adult, she didn’t’ have to shut
up and that she did not have to worrying about this one, referring to Youth 3;
that she swear she does not.
 Case Manager C advised the other youth to sit; and for Youth 3 not to try to
tell the female youth what to do.
 Case Manager 3 was not heard cursing Youth 3, putting hands on him, in his
face or threatening to throw or hurt him.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12206 Staff qualifications
(1) An agency shall require a staff member who has
ongoing contact with children or parents to be a person
who has the ability, experience, education, and training to
perform the duties assigned.
ANALYSIS: The evidence does not support the allegations as reported.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
During the course of the investigation the following was observed at the Balfour IL
house. I visited this home after 5:00pm:
10

 Youth 3-bedroom door being broken off the hinges at the top. Youth 3 denied
him or someone else breaking the door. He reported there were always issues
with the door. He said the door has been like that for over a week. The more he
opened and closed the door the worst it got with the nail coming unscrewed. He
expressed privacy concerns due to the door issue.
 A very large hole in the wall upstairs going to the bedroom. Additionally various
smaller holes in the walls of the upper bedroom. All of which did not appears to
be recent. Staff E, Youth 3, Youth 4, and Youth 5 denied knowing how long the
wall damage had exited or how it happened. Youth 3 reported the big hole was
there when he arrived. He said it’s likely been there for a month because of
another youth living there and reporting a concern. Youth 3 admitted there have
been things broken by residents due to fights, like the tv. He denied youths
fighting and damaging the walls.
Program Manager B reported the damages did not exit prior to my visit to the
home on 10/15/2021. She reported being at the home around 2:15pm on
10/15/2021 and the holes were not there. She said the three youths at this home
moved in two weeks ago; and the home was in good repair. She reported seeing
the one hole later and agreed it looked as if a person could fit in the hole. She
provided me a picture of a large wall hole, which was not the hole I had
referenced. She reported later that the picture she provided me was a new hole
in the living in room which happened since my visit. This was just to show how
that too had just happened Program Manager B reported the residents wrestle,
and this may be how the damage occurred. She said the residents break and
damage things and they repair them. She reports the repairs have been made to
these issues. She reported when damages occur, and the staff or resident
reports them and they have maintenance to make repairs quickly.
Case Manager F reported most of the residents at the Balfour address are on her
case load. She reported visiting the home recently (no specific day given). She
did not recall seeing holes in the walls, nor a wet, dirty basement with hanging
wires.
YASA G reported doing a walkthrough of this house on 10/14/2021; and that the
holes were not there. She said and other staff concluded Youth 3 and Youth 4
who are large youths horseplay, and their behavior caused the damage.
 Extremely dirty and wet basement with hanging wires. Staff E and the youths
residing at this site reported they did not know how long the basement has been
in its current condition. YASA G reported the sink in the kitchen was leaking and
that’s where the water/wet basement floor was from.
11

Program manager B and YASA G reported all the things have been fixed. On
12/8/2021, Program Manager B provided me a picture of a basement area which
showed the laundry tub and floor. That small area appeared clean and dry.
However, the picture was not of the entire basement area and did not show the
basement ceiling area, so as to reveal that no wires were hanging.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision.
(b) At monthly interval, ensure that the youth is complying
with the terms of the contract required by R400.1210,
continues to resident in a safe and acceptable environment,
and it is managing expenditures.
ANALYSIS: The agency’s Balfour IL home showed holes in the walls, a
bedroom door broken from it hinges, creating a privacy issue;
and a dirty, wet basement with wires hanging from the ceiling.
All of these are possible safety issues and do not comply with
this rule related to acceptable and safe environment.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon a receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, continuation of the agency’s
current licensing plan is recommended.
12/17/2021
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 21, 2021
________________________________________
Linda Tansil Date
Area Manager
12
